And let's talk about this asynchronous
compute or async compute as I'm going to
call it. The very basic explanation is
that you can optionally launch compute
work on a separate queue next to the
graphics queue. This will give the GPU a
chance to overlap compute with graphics
work when there's room for both. And
often times there is room since, you
know, shaders are never really scheduled
with 100% resource utilization. So this
gives us a way to shorten the overall
frame by going a little wider.

Yes, but let's talk about hitches. So,
as I mentioned before, dynamic
resolution works by measuring the cost
of past frames to determine the the
resolution we need to keep the next
frames in budget.
So if there's suddenly a frame with an
outsized cost, it's not going to have
time to react and mitigate. So we run
the risk of dropping a frame. And if
this happens regularly, it can
negatively impact the experience and
make it feel inconsistent. This is what
we call hitching. And the source of
these hitches on the GPU can be a number
of things like spawning expensive
effects or some larger buffer
reallocation.
And a very common one is camera cuts
because we rely on previous frame data
to effectively do occlusion culling. And
if the camera swaps to some other random
view, we lose all that data and we have
to render a lot more things with a lot
more overdraw.
Cinematics and conversations are typical
examples of this like this one where
this merchants gets devoured by the
manticor.

system which will prime the lost data
after a camera cut with lower resolution
data from the rate tracing scene. This

after a camera cut, but instead have at
